guild.description:
"For God so loved the world, that He gave His only begotten Son, that whoever believes in Him shall not perish, but have eternal life. For God did not send the Son into the world to judge the world, but that the world might be saved through Him. He who believes in Him is not judged; he who does not believe has been judged already, because he has not believed in the name of the only begotten Son of God. This is the judgment, that the Light has come into the world, and men loved the darkness rather than the Light, for their deeds were evil. For everyone who does evil hates the Light, and does not come to the Light for fear that his deeds will be exposed. But he who practices the truth comes to the Light, so that his deeds may be manifested as having been wrought in God."

May all personally encounter the presence and attention of the Lord God. 

Curiosity, questions, discussion, and prayer requests are welcome.

body:
I'm an Amerimutt but I'm mostly anglo and Germanic. Which means I'm probably going to talk to Protestants first, I think.

Maybe I'll ask my old man what churches my Grandparents went to. Both of my Gen-X parents completely failed to carry on that tradition.

body: It's a damn shame. But on the other hand, a lot of idiots rebel after being raised in the church, especially in their teenage years. God finds you, whether raised in the church tradition or not. Always remember that being around other Christians will keep you accountable, so don't stop making church a priority -- someone might need you one day. Your parents dismissed that for some reason.

author.bio: Conservative and no, I won't sit down and shut up.
author.bio_html: Conservative and no, I won't sit down and shut up.

body:
Go to a church.
If the minister uses the Bible as a prop, and rarely reads from it, never go back.
If the minister says things like "I think," a lot, go somewhere else. If he often says "The Bible tells us," and then proceeds to read from it, it may be a good place to stay a while.
If the minister never (or rarely) puts things in context by explaining the culture of the time and place his references were written, then look for a better place. It may be possible to suggest this to him, and he may listen.
If he jumps around a lot and won't focus on one course of study over a few weeks, it is probably best to go elsewhere. And above all, if the minister even HINTS that we should go along to get along in order to spread the word to as many as possible, run fast and run far. Those are some of the first things I look for in a new church.
body_html:
Go to a church.
If the minister uses the Bible as a prop, and rarely reads from it, never go back.
If the minister says things like "I think," a lot, go somewhere else. If he often says "The Bible tells us," and then proceeds to read from it, it may be a good place to stay a while.
If the minister never (or rarely) puts things in context by explaining the culture of the time and place his references were written, then look for a better place. It may be possible to suggest this to him, and he may listen.
If he jumps around a lot and won't focus on one course of study over a few weeks, it is probably best to go elsewhere.

And above all, if the minister even HINTS that we should go along to get along in order to spread the word to as many as possible, run fast and run far.

Those are some of the first things I look for in a new church.

body: Yeah, go for it! Protestants are definitely the most fragmented when it comes to unified teachings, which can be as beneficial as it is annoying, so if you don't think your grandparents' church is based in reality, you might have to do some looking around with different congregations. On the bright side, being in America means there will be a church every other block, so you'll have no shortage when it comes to that. I'll be praying you find the right one!

body:
> If he often says "The Bible tells us," and then proceeds to read from it, it may be a good place to stay a while.

Except that's just as bad. It should be "Jesus says". The bible is full of interpolations and is easy to twist any way you want. People act like the bible is a book God just dropped out of the sky one day, written fully in English. While that would be easier, it's an invention of the catholic church in 382 AD. I've also noticed that "bible believers" conveniently avoid the gospels most of the time, literally the most important part, probably because they contradict their agenda.

> And above all, if the minister even HINTS that we should go along to get along in order to spread the word to as many as possible, run fast and run far.

Why is spreading the word a bad thing? Isn't that exactly what we're commanded to do?
body_html:
If he often says "The Bible tells us," and then proceeds to read from it, it may be a good place to stay a while.

Except that's just as bad. It should be "Jesus says". The bible is full of interpolations and is easy to twist any way you want. People act like the bible is a book God just dropped out of the sky one day, written fully in English. While that would be easier, it's an invention of the catholic church in 382 AD. I've also noticed that "bible believers" conveniently avoid the gospels most of the time, literally the most important part, probably because they contradict their agenda.

And above all, if the minister even HINTS that we should go along to get along in order to spread the word to as many as possible, run fast and run far.

Why is spreading the word a bad thing? Isn't that exactly what we're commanded to do?

guild.description:
"For God so loved the world, that He gave His only begotten Son, that whoever believes in Him shall not perish, but have eternal life. For God did not send the Son into the world to judge the world, but that the world might be saved through Him. He who believes in Him is not judged; he who does not believe has been judged already, because he has not believed in the name of the only begotten Son of God. This is the judgment, that the Light has come into the world, and men loved the darkness rather than the Light, for their deeds were evil. For everyone who does evil hates the Light, and does not come to the Light for fear that his deeds will be exposed. But he who practices the truth comes to the Light, so that his deeds may be manifested as having been wrought in God."

May all personally encounter the presence and attention of the Lord God. 

Curiosity, questions, discussion, and prayer requests are welcome.
guild.description_html:
"For God so loved the world, that He gave His only begotten Son, that whoever believes in Him shall not perish, but have eternal life. For God did not send the Son into the world to judge the world, but that the world might be saved through Him. He who believes in Him is not judged; he who does not believe has been judged already, because he has not believed in the name of the only begotten Son of God. This is the judgment, that the Light has come into the world, and men loved the darkness rather than the Light, for their deeds were evil. For everyone who does evil hates the Light, and does not come to the Light for fear that his deeds will be exposed. But he who practices the truth comes to the Light, so that his deeds may be manifested as having been wrought in God."

May all personally encounter the presence and attention of the Lord God.

Curiosity, questions, discussion, and prayer requests are welcome.
guild.name: Christianity

parent.body:
Go to a church.
If the minister uses the Bible as a prop, and rarely reads from it, never go back.
If the minister says things like "I think," a lot, go somewhere else. If he often says "The Bible tells us," and then proceeds to read from it, it may be a good place to stay a while.
If the minister never (or rarely) puts things in context by explaining the culture of the time and place his references were written, then look for a better place. It may be possible to suggest this to him, and he may listen.
If he jumps around a lot and won't focus on one course of study over a few weeks, it is probably best to go elsewhere. And above all, if the minister even HINTS that we should go along to get along in order to spread the word to as many as possible, run fast and run far. Those are some of the first things I look for in a new church.
parent.body_html:
Go to a church.
If the minister uses the Bible as a prop, and rarely reads from it, never go back.
If the minister says things like "I think," a lot, go somewhere else. If he often says "The Bible tells us," and then proceeds to read from it, it may be a good place to stay a while.
If the minister never (or rarely) puts things in context by explaining the culture of the time and place his references were written, then look for a better place. It may be possible to suggest this to him, and he may listen.
If he jumps around a lot and won't focus on one course of study over a few weeks, it is probably best to go elsewhere.

And above all, if the minister even HINTS that we should go along to get along in order to spread the word to as many as possible, run fast and run far.

Those are some of the first things I look for in a new church.

author.bio: Conservative and no, I won't sit down and shut up.
author.bio_html: Conservative and no, I won't sit down and shut up.

body:
The point was to contrast with the "I think" from the previous sentence.

We are to spread the word. But we are not to conform to the world in order to do so. We are to conform to God, and that often puts us in conflict with the world.
